"It's tough for a House member to run for president," this strategist continues, and it looks like he will waltz into the governorship of Indiana. He must be thinking,` I've got Tim Pawlentye, and it's a lot easier to run as the governor of Indiana than as a House member from anywhere.' The source close to Mike Pence agrees. As governor, he'll be able "to build a larger following and donor base" and address "the punditry that says you need executive experience."

candidate with strong Indiana roots to contrast Mike Pence 's prominence in Washington. Parker described Mike Pence as a partisan ideologue who wouldn't fit well with Indiana voters who he said typically favor centrist candidates. The one thing most Hoosiers would say they don't want in Indianapolis at the Statehouse is Washington politics, Parker said. "He's used to the Washington game of lay blame and be partisan. American Idol's season-one co-host Brian Dunkleman admits to having been extremely freaked out the first time he saw Simon Cowell tell someone they should never sing again. It's one thing to watch it on television, but then you spend time with these kids and you have to look at them right in the eyes, and then their mother is looking at you, like,` What just happened?'?
